review_title: Old Game But Still Fun to Play
one_reviews_text:
Story:
You are stuck in a zombie apocalypse somewhere in the middle of the desert. You must get out of the area and deal with zombies in the meantime. Grab pistols, shotguns, smg's, grenades,a sniper, and even a minigun to ward off the incoming waves of zombies. You make your way across many different segments of the map, including a terrifying mineshaft, a prison, and many more locations each stuffed with new weapons, excitement, and more zombies! Plus there are DLC packs that you can purchase which expand upon the story and add a bit more gameplay. 
   GAMEPLAY:
You can choose between multiple different movement modes, including snap turning, teleportation, or smooth locomotion. I have Boneworks and for those of you that don't know, it has the most realistic interaction physics ever created. And that kind of made the interaction in this game underwhelming. In Arizona Sunshine you can't climb ladders, you simply walk up to a ladder and are teleported up or down. The mechanics in this game are kind of old in my opinion, but this game was released in 2016, at the start of VR gaming popularity. 
   SOUNDS:
The gun sounds in this game I think are really well done. They are loud and differ with every weapon. By the way your in-game character talks quite a bit, which is kind of entertaining listening to. Especially during the big f-bomb hurddle. If you play multiplayer you can chat to your partner. Something that is pretty cool is that your voice echos in certain places of the game, like long tunnels. +1 for immersion. 
   All in all I think this game is pretty great. If you want to get more comfortable to VR gaming I think it would be a good idea buying this game. For veteran vr users this may not satisfy everyone, but satisfy me it did! 
 
                                      8/10

review_title: Decent zombie shooter, lots of bugs
one_reviews_text:
First off, I got this on the Quest and really enjoyed it. The campaign is what I played most and it's your typical zombie story. Go from point A to point B while finding keys, opening car doors, and shooting zombies. The gunplay is fun and simplistic. That being said, there are a lot of issues with the game.
- Voice acting. Your character sounds good and you can tell the guy was into the role, but after an hour or so he gets PAINFULLY annoying. You'll be rolling your eyes at every little comment he makes on every single thing.
- Glitches galore; I've run into guns getting stuck in mid-air, zombies attacking me through walls, not being able to fire one of my guns, LOSING one or all of my weapons on loading a save, not being able to pick ammo up. There are tons of bugs throughout the game.
- No melee combat. You'll find that you can throw objects at zombies with little to no effect, but if they get too close, you have no option to punch/hit them. Missed opportunity here, as zombies do crowd you frequently and the only way out is to wildly shoot before you die.
- No 2-handed weapons in the campaign. All of the guns you encounter are either pistols, SMGs, or a tiny shotgun pistol. You do get to use a sniper rifle and minigun, but both are tethered to a barrier. The only place I've found rifles are in the endless waves mode. You get a bunch of them there.
- No option for realistic reloading. When you run out of ammo, you just push a button to release the magazine, and put the gun to your chest. An option to allow you to actually push a new one into the gun would've been great.

Other than that, I'd only recommend the base game if you can get it on sale between 20-15 dollars. It's a rather fun, but barebones shooter with a bunch of bugs if you can bare them. I beat the story mode in about 4 hours on hard difficulty.

review_title: Not nearly as good as the reviews say...
one_reviews_text:
The fact that this game often still appears on "best VR games" lists really shows what a dire state VR gaming is in nearly three years after it's initial release.

Arizona Sunshine is a mundane, linear shooter with an uninspired and totally unoriginal zombie apocalypse storyline which we've all seen before. The VR gunplay is average at best, and the game's levels are rather boring and reuse the same bland environment throughout. The entire game involves just popping zombies from as far away as possible, with the occasional highly predictable "swarm" to offer some kind of challenge. In addition, the protagonist is an annoying idiot who's "jokes" are lame, predictable, and not remotely humorous.

The long and short of it is that they may as well have done away with the so-called "story" and just made this game a pointless wave shooter. It did almost nothing to show off the capabilities of VR three years ago, and it does even less now. You're far better off spending your money elsewhere, unless you can grab this in a 90%-off sale. There are much, much better VR titles out there.

The multiplayer is the best aspect of the game. Hord mode could do with more maps and more the campaign could do with more than two players but other than that it's my favourite game of all time. More game would be good so I'm definately going to pick up this next DLC

review_title: Still needs a lot of work
one_reviews_text: Was really looking forward to this game (also considering the many positive reviews), but the thing is that this game just keeps on crashing and crashing (using different settings, Nvidia drivers, fresh Oculus install, etc). Between the crashes it's a decent game (with fairly nice graphics (although still a bit wobbly/buggy now and then), sound design, etc), with a decent narrative, but it's absolutely not worth its full prize. Since I purchased this for a couple of bucks (with some of the highly valued Oculus credits we received recently), it doesn't hurt me too much, but overall I'm still pretty disappointed (cause I was looking forward to playing this). There are a number of VR-games out there (f.e. Lone Echo, Arktika.1) that are way better in my view, regarding graphics, interaction level, sound design, narrative, weapons design, atmosphere and the overall quality of build. Sorry to say that I cannot recommend this game (and I certainly wasn't expecting this when I bought it, also due to the fact that I'm more forgiving towards VR-games cause of their experimental nature). So for now I'll give it a 1-star rating, but if build quality would be improved substantially (f.e. by removing the bugs that make this game almost unplayable), I guess it could go up to 3 or maybe even 4 stars, who knows ;-) [edit: since the last time I've played this game, maybe a year ago, it has become a better, more stable game, so now I'm finally able to enjoy this game, 4 stars it is).

I think the game is good and what most people say is true. 

But if you've played the more polished games before (Gorn, Robot Recall, etc) you will really feel how old that game is in VR time. Locomotion is pretty bad, I got stuck just at the end of the game with no options but to restart the whole chapter. There's a lot of things you would expect from a VR game that this game has not, melee combat, multiplayer head movement, smoothing of multiplayer movement, better physics and handling of world objects (if you have a key, you don't get to put the key in the hole for example) and other things along those lines. 

I'm sure this game has been a big pillar for a lot of newer VR games, but if you expect polished gameplay, you might want to look elsewhere.

There's not much going on in the game besides ammo, guns, and zombies. There are masks you can put on, and some ducks hidden around the maps. Zombies are fun to kill. Aiming is mostly precise, allowing you to hone your skill in aiming down the sights. Ammo management can get tricky. Reload mechanic is very simple (empty clip, move weapon to belt), and makes it easy to get out of sticky situations. Weapons of the same class are pretty interchangeable. I do feel like sometimes I shoot the head and it doesn't register, or they barely block it with a limb. I use smooth turning and walk locomotion. The teleportation was frustrating to me.

Horde mode is fun, but once you get the feel for it, it's possible to get to high levels pretty easy. I played for like 3 hours straight and just wanted to die already (was around 30th on the leaderboard). I'll keep going back to horde mode and co-op campaign. Overall it's been a lot of fun.

I agree with every positive review about this game, most notably its great atmosphere and realistic guns. However I do like to point out its flaws and what could be improved.

ALIASING: Although the game's graphics has realistic textures and lighting, it has the WORST aliasing problem I've seen in any game I've played in VR. This is especially noticable in dark environments with bright spotlights overhead; the jagged highlights shimmer like fireflies in the distance and are very distracting. This is less of a problem in daylight areas. Thankfully the immersion aspect of VR makes up for this problem; if this was a regular flat-screen game it would score a 1/10 in graphics for today's standards.

CATCHING MAGAZINES: When in-between zombie encounters I'd like my gun to be fully loaded. So I eject the magazine currently in the gun and reload with a fresh new one from my belt. But the ejected magazine still has bullets so I have to pick it up from the ground and return the bullets to my belt. I just wish I could catch the magazine as it falls off the gun, instead of having to bend down and pick it up.

GRENADE THROWING: I am a fully-grown adult with a trim, athetic body. However I feel like I have the muscle power of a 3-year-old child when I try to throw grenades in a normal overhand throw. Tossing them in an underhand makes them go further for some reason. They really need to put more acceleration into these things.

To conclude my review, I'd give this game 5 stars. But the aliasing problem in the graphics is too much of a concern for me, graphics-wise. So I subtract 1 star. 4 stars in total.

review_title: Exactly what I was looking for
one_reviews_text:
Motion Sickness,
I am happy to say this game brought no such issues, and plays much like Robo Recall. (Motion Sickness stopped me playing Mage's Tale, so is a big concern when trying out new games)

Campaign,
No complaints, I didn't want it to end, but I couldn't stop playing until it did, and I don't feel like it was too short either.

Story,
Not, much to say, it is a means to justify your zombie killing spree not much more.

Gameplay,
At any one time you can carry 2 weapons on your belt, and 2 in your hands - I would have liked to be able to carry more but it doesn't impact the game by not.
The momenent uses teleportation, or free move (though it is not true teleportation as you must teleport to somewhere that you could have walked to in a straight line, thus you must teleport round a table not over it, and you can't teleport past a zombie) Both methods of moving are much the same in terms of gameplay, so don't expect either to handicap you.

Issues,
From my experience anyway, the two handed weapons dont work that well. I found myself often just weilding the bigger weapons with one hand anyway, as there was very little difference with aim, and it allowed me to use a second weapon.
Also, there isn't much in the way of a tutorial (Not that it really needs one) but there are little things that I missed as a result - I didn't know that you can store Grenades on a seperate section on your chest until I googled it afterwards.

Overall,
Brilliant, I am recommending this game to friends and family, and hope to try out the multiplayer stuff soon.

In my opinion,  this is another "top 10" game for the Oculus Rift.  I love that the main character (you) talks out loud to himself as you go through the game.  He really helps give you the feel that your a 'sole survivor' who's just barely holding on to his sanity, subject to fits of semi-macabre humor,  anger, and even depression;  all while fighting zombies, zombie hordes, and trying to find his way to a human enclave.

I also love that the weapons in the game feel realistic and there are no fancy gimmicks like laser scopes and other high-tech features;  you use your iron sights like [insert favorite deity here] intended.  The weapon variety is interesting too,  where you'll get a gun with night sights and not think much about it until later on when you're in a dark mine shaft.  You scavenge around for ammo,  which thankfully is fairly pentiful, and find interesting pistols (of all varieties, calibers, and with various features), sub-machine guns, shot guns, etc.  You're given an ammo belt that holds all your spare clips, shotgun shells,  grenades, and grenade launcher ammo.  When you find ammo,  you have to pick it up and put it on your ammo belt (where it auto attaches) and to reload,  you have to click a button to eject the spent clip from your weapon,  then touch the weapon to your ammo belt.  It's a good loading mechanic that gives you more of a real-world feel, without being too tedious. I also love that you can dual-wield and even easily switch weapons between hands should you want to.  In total you can carry four weapons;  one in each hand, and one on each hip,  where you simply reach down and 'grab' to swap weapons.

The story line is fun, funny at times, and keeps you interested in moving forward and trying to find a human settlement.  10/10 would buy again.

First off, buy this game on sale. 2 hours of single player campaign. 

Cons:
-The iron sights on the guns are useless and requires you to use a laser type sight instead. If you've been trained to use iron sights, like myself, it Effs with your head as you'll constantly find yourself shooting low. 
-Bad performance. I7 4.GHz & 1080 GTX. Zombies look like a slide show as they're running at me, frame drops and general shuddering.
-Terrible tracking. This is the only game that I've played that looses tracking of my controllers, constantly!
-Bad, Terrible, God Awful lighting. Some places are like playing in a vacuum where there is only light and complete darkness. The flash light is creates just a little circle of light while everything else is inky blackness. This hurt my eyes and my head. Also, some of the light sources in the game are better left turned off. All they do is blind you and hide enemies behind the blinding glare. 
-Clunky Locomotion. You'll find yourself handing up on almost every rock or edge. Be careful if using room scale as a simple step in any direction can cause you get caught in the game geometry, especially with a horde of Freds after you.
-Graphical glitches. It's like playing Fallout 4 VR all over again. Shimmering textures, buggy geometry, clipping issues galore. 

Pros:
-Funny dialog.
-Zombie damage is entertaining
-Decent game flow. I think this may be this games strongest asset as I found it with just enough casual exploring verses frantically shoot at zombie waves. 
-Story drives player progression. I found the single player story just compelling enough to make it through the whole game (a whole two hours) in one session.

I had already bought a couple of zombie shooter games. With the amount of shooting games that are available in the Oculus store, I wasn't too thrilled to play this game, boy was I wrong !  The game started like any other zombie game, you shoot one zombie here and a couple over there and the game makes you feel like there's nothing new you haven't experienced. It's after the first level that I started to play for longer periods of time. The graphics are really good. You get the opportunity to experience the use of a good amount of different types of firearms. The voice/dialogue is amazing ! The controls are really good. If you get stuck on a wall, try to move your face away from the wall to regain control of your character.  If I remember correctly, there's an automatic save check point half way through all the levels.  Oculus games aren't that big in general, sure this game is not as big as a console or PC game, but it's still decently bigger than most Oculus games. There's only music playing in certain parts of the game, giving it a really good zombie apocalyptic atmosphere !  Even though it's a horror game, they opted out from using jump scare elements, which I think it's better, they didn't have a need to use them. Instead, you get this creepy atmosphere.  Although you could put yourself in scare jump situations. Even though there isn't much of a story, it's fascinating to see how your character's story unfolds as he tries to survive. Also, the Campaign title screen shows that there's an option for 2 players, don't know exactly how that works. There's also a " Horde Mode " that I haven't tried. No wonder they don't lower the price for this game. Even though I bought it on special, this game is worth it at full price. Like I said, this is a must have game to add to your library !

Wandering the highways and looting cars by physically opening the doors, bending over and rummaging through the stuff inside brings a weird sense of immersion.

It especially shines if you have a friend to tag along and share in the sense of panic when you get swarmed, or to stand with, back to back, as you make your last stand.

I think at this point this game should populate most libraries.

Some of the movement mechanics, even with teleportation were a bit off, with small pieces of garbage or junk blocking movement where it shouldn't have been an issue.  I wouldn't call it a AAA game... but certainly enjoyable and worth a look.
Graphics look great, gun handling, ammo loading, locomotion are all smooth and work as I would expect. I want something like this but more open. The story is good, good dark humor, worth replaying!

I have to compliment the developers....right now VR is in its infancy, yet rather than just put out a stand in spot shoot zombie game which in these early days of VR would still be acceptable and fairly common, they instead added a impressive amount of world interaction in this game. I knew it from when I put the winch in and rolled down the bridge,opened up doors and trunks to vehicles and closed the door on approaching zombies when I was in an office.these developers obviously meant business. I have to also say my heart skips a beat how, yes VR works, it puts you IN the game...but even better, some of the zombies like the faster ones, man...you really feel they "see" you and they look like they are very determined to get at you how they focus on you and you see their distorted faces and it appears they lock eyes with you. seriously it sends chills down my spine when one of the taller or faster ones get near. oh, and just hearing the character cackle when he finds grenades...that was certainly a moment LMFAO  .yes...it has flaws, looking far out things appear low res, and you dont have alot of roaming abilities,its a small game area and gun aiming is off...but you have to hand it to the developers for creating in my mind one of the first games that leads the way on the possibilities of VR. oh, one more thing developers....THANK YOU for implementing regular locomotion. I will never understand why game makers create these game worlds and then....leave out the ability to walk/run as we do in regular life. it totally defeats the purpose of VR. I understand some get sick in VR. well I dont, so thanks for not punishing me. one more side bonus...as someone who lives in an area that is bombarded with snow...it really had an unintended ability to give me an escape from the depressing grey skies here with the sun bleached look. and my ceiling fan simulating wind sealed the deal.another consequence of the power of VR. great job developers. cant wait to see what you do next.

I seriously LOVE this game! The character's dialog to the action packed moments where you're surrounded by the undead.  BUT! Everytime I try to join matchmaking, it just Crashes! Please respond if you read this :)

A very solid VR FPS game. This is a full-blooded FPS adventure that’ll see you travelling across Arizona in search of other survivors of the Zombie Apocalypse. The shooting mechanics are excellent, the touch controllers work wonders in it and the whole game feels polished.

It would have been nice if they had added some human foes. As the zombies don’t do much more than run/walk at you. They can still be pretty dangerous when they come as a horde, and on normal difficulty the game gave me a good challenge. But I would have liked to have things mixed up a bit with a few fire-fights with hostile humans and the like. 

Still, this is a sizable experience. It’s well made and should offer you a lot of value for money. Highly recommended.

I don't get the negative reviews.  This is probably one of the best VR games I've played.  I've tried a few of them including Robo Recal, which is good but this is better.  I recommend this on the basis of my 4 hour binge playing.  I will say this, you need to play this standing up to get the most of it.

This is a great triple A title, full of humour and great gunplay.  I’m glad they included full locomotion; I just think teleporting mechanic is such a wasted opportunity when you want to explore the game world.  It is still one of the best games out there; if it is on sale buy it without hesitation.
As for the complainers?  Graphics? crank up the supersampling as far a your system can take it (goes without saying by now).  Short single player?  Play it on a harder setting and get your moneys worth.  Bad aiming?  Use the sights, all I can say is that if you use the gun sites correctly you will get a head shot every time; they may have corrected something or people may be used to some sort of auto-aim mechanic in other games, but seriously there is no issue with aiming.
This is in my top 3 of the best vr game i have played.
Great game, had a lot of fun. But it got a 4 star, because it is too short.

review_title: Its could do with a tweak or two
one_reviews_text:
First of all this game is a nice single player game and is great to play. Butttt
I first got this game on steam as I was given a gift card for Steam, but could not get the game to work on my Rift touch controllers so ended up getting a refund and buying it from Oculus store now works great (in single player only)
The reason I wanted this was to play co-op with friends, but every time I get a invite all I get is the steam store page coming up asking me to buy it?? I try to invite friends only to have no one join??
So for me as a single player game it is fine and a good VR game as a multi/co-op game it needs tweaking/fixing so no matter what store you get it from it will work as it should, and thats why it only gets 3 stars as I can not play it as I wanted it too.

this is a great game . i would not call it a full game . but as far as a VR shooter this is top notch . the aiming needs work. ai is a little ehhh . very imersive game . story line should be a lot longer i finshed the game in 2 hours . and that was relaxed play .grafix are not all that bad . the horde mode is fun for a bit it just to slow .co op is fun too . over all i give the game 3.5 .

this is not a starter VR game but it is very well done for someone more experienced with fast reaction time seeing as the zombies can get out of hand pretty fast but graphics are great and game runs very smooth. BUY A 3RD SENSOR FOR THIS GAME its worth it

Graphics are ok, but thats the only good think I can say, glitches so many time during gameplay but the WORST feature is you are unable to shoot straight, even my 10 year old son said 'why can't i shoot straight like on the other zombie games' that speaks volumes that even a 10 year can see. In its current format it is unplayable and NOT fun!

review_title: One of the best early VR games
one_reviews_text:
This was one of the first VR games with an actual single player story that I played. The world is really interesting to go through and the action is a lot of fun.

There are a good variety of locations and interesting things to explore. It's basically a horde shooter with a story, and that's totally fine with me.

This is amazing! This is one of the best vr games i have ever played.
The graphics are great, There are alot of diffrent weapons, the shooting feels really good and the dialogue is funny.
And for the people crashing try lowering the settings, that helped me :D

So... I suppose it was made with Unity, and it shows... Also as other already said, crooked aim is crooked. I actually suspect it's a feature to make the game more challenging, but it's frustrating. I'm by no mean a sharpshooter IRL but my aim is fairly ok, here I can't get a feel for proper targeting in this game. Other than that nice idea and okay sound design. Just needs to be re-done in Unreal and allow you to, you know, aim properly.
Fantastic game start to finish. Loved the final battle

Game is pretty much what you'd expect. Good voice acting and dialog from the character. Graphics are a big deal for me and this game is not exactly up to par with current games. Still fun shooting zombies in the face. Just wish you could use melee weapons. Overall pretty basic game dunno if it's worth the price tag.
deff my favorite game iv played

review_title: Crashes every time I try to play
one_reviews_text:
Brand new i7-7700, GTX 1070, 16GB Ram, SSD, 100Mbit connection. Can't play for more than 2 minutes without it freezing. Only game I have had problems with.

Update: In campaign, I can't get past the head rolling out of the cave. As soon as I look at the head, it freezes.

All the little bugs i can deal with, but the extremely short single player campaign is enoying aswell as your player never finding a single (Alive) person is ennoying and the ending kinda sucked. The horde mode looks great but matchmaking is broken, once again it takes the fun out. This game has been up nearly a year and it looks like nothing has changed. Note to devs - Fix the little bugs, fix multiplayer and make a new free mode with something a little more than just killing zombies. Now with the bad stuff out the way. I enjoyed this game alot in terms of killing zombies. The realness of going underground and it being so dark was scary. There is alot of really nice guns to handle including a glock 17 with a flash light, an m9, an uzi and many more. The way you scavenge for ammo is awesome, i love it, but once again that is all you scavenge for, apart from the odd burger you can eat to gain health. I dont reccomend you pay £30 for this game, wait till the price drops or until the devs update the game. This is only a play once game, there is nothing to make me go back and play more since the multiplayer dont work and there is no free mode and you cant do anything but kill zombies. You cant build, you cant explore, you cant scavenge anything but ammo. I hope devs take this into consideration when pricing something so high.
Pretty fun game

review_title: Best FPS VR Title so far
one_reviews_text: This game is definately my favourite VR title, it's a great shooter. The looting is fantastic, actually searching cars, draws or containers for supplies. HIghly recommended

review_title: So good I bought it twice!
one_reviews_text:
Well, I had issues on the Steam version, apparently due to using the beta version so of the two options to use release steam or beta, or buy it on Oculus Home (and thereby support both the devs, who have been speaking to players on Steam and promising updates and/or content, and Oculus) I decided to buy it here, too. After all, I paid a sale price orginally, so....
I do enjoy it - but on Steam there were issues (as mentioned) so now I can play it flawlessly on Oculus Home - just as it should be.

review_title: The actor's main character voice is fun.
one_reviews_text: Very cool/funny monologue by main protagonist. His voice was spot on. Good graphics/locations/guns and sense of place. The single player experience is worth your time. The mine level rocks!
The movement in the game def needs some adjusting but overall the game is fun. I love shotting things and killing zombies so I found this game very entertaining.
Can't shoot anything even when its 2 ft from my face. can't calibrate the controls because it hangs at the loading screen. I want to like this game so far its trash.

While it sure is entertaining to shoot zombies, the game constantly frustrates and ultimately creates an unsatisfactory experience.  The UI is clumsy and awkward.  I enjoy most titles with teleport-based movement, but somehow they turned it into a pain.  The constant hunt for precious ammo drains your energy as well, as I just want to blast things, not hunt around opening every drawer or car, or have to wait till the zombies are 2 feet away before I shoot them to make sure I get headshots.  Reloading is awkward as well.  I think these are all challenges with any vr shooter, but in my opinion Arizona Sunshine didn't quite pull it off.

I WANTED to love it! It is completely, amazingly immersive, and the controls, aiming, etc. all feel right. But there are SO many bugs and glitches that it feels like early-access. The worst is that if you die late in a level, you WILL be restarting the whole level. The "checkpoint" bit doesn't really work, because you respawn at the checkpoint, but the game is then so glitched that it's basically unplayable. Ammo doesn't work correctly (reloads don't give you full ammo on, for example, the shotty), and the zombies glitch forward/sideways, etc. WHEN you then die again, the game green-screens (crashes). And then, you MUST restart the whole level. So, DON'T DIE. EVER! Multiplayer is still not ready for prime-time, despite the supposed fixes. My partner would de-sync at very bad moments! This game could be the best ever! But at present it is FAR, FAR from that. NOT worth the $40 at present. Wait for a sale or for MANY more patches before you waste your time/money on it.
Amazing! Controls work perfectly, great thrilling gameplay, funny commentary and a nice easy plot - survive. 5/5.
While I agree the price is rather high for the amount of content, the content itself is very polished and well worth the money.  I got the game at daily deal price and that made it even better!

While not especially long (2-3 hours) this is far from just being an "experience" - there's a story, you can explore the various locations you pass through for ammo, weapons and health restoring food, and the action is genuinely exciting.

Playing in co-op is definitely worthwhile, forcing you to carefully ration out who takes which weapons and ammo (except on easy where bullets are plentiful)

I chose to play without teleportation, finding the independent movement to be more fun for me.  My first hour of play left me feeling a little queasy, but I returned to the game a day later and played through the full story with no ill effects.  For those who suffer from motion sickness, the teleport system appears to work well.

Aiming can be a little wonky at times - where the touch controllers feel like they should be straight is generally a few degrees off for the guns.

I'd definitely list this as one of the Must Have titles for VR.

Seriously - this is just a BAD waveshooter! No actual story, VERY bad controlls and movement, mediocre graphics (to be nice). I really don't get the hype they created. I would say it's good for 10,- bucks. But not for 30,- oder even more. 

Important for german users: DON'T TRY THE GERMAN VOICES! It's the worst voiceacting I ever experienced in a game at all!

I was liking the game (nice graphics, superb voice acting) but, my saves become corrupt (black sceen for at least 5 minutes when loading). It seems you can't save in this game so any amount of progression has to be done in single sittings or don't shut down the game if you want to continue later. Oh and, accessing the options menu while in game resets your progress - yeah, not fun.

Don't pay full price for this game! It's truley not that bad of a game, but its not worth the full price. Searching through GIANT cars for ammo, and no option for full locomotion just makes vr, and especially this vr expierience feel gimmicky. Needs more polish and a hefty price cut imho.
seriously this is really good. graphics are ok as it's also made to work on psvr. the experience makes up for it. it looks real enough to get into it

review_title: Must have for Zombie & VR lovers
one_reviews_text: Great gameplay and decently long story. With decent replay value. A must have for your VR library if your a fan of Zombie killing.
I am really enjoying this game. This is what VR made for. Many many goosebumps specially in the dark mine level. Great work.
possibly one of the worst games i have played so expensive and it is broken as hell, zombies teleporting thats not fun.

After playing Robo Recall, this game feels really clunky. Gameplay is decent, but the mechanics don't work extremely well without a full 360 setup (with a 3rd camera). There's no ground marker to tell where you're facing, and it's easy to get confused with the movement system. Game is pretty short, and doens't feel like there's much replay value either.

Wow, I just finished Arizona Sunshine and I am super excited to share this with friends and family. It's amazing how realistic the shooting mechanics are! I have spent many hours on the shooting range and let me tell you the same principles apply when shooting in this game (hint: keep your focus on the front sight). 

The belt issue is easily solved by calibrating, I am shocked how many people do not pay attention and do not read -_-

I did not use the other locomotion types because the teleportation is was good enough. I might try it again with the walking locomotion on the next playthrough. 

I definately recommend everyone buy this game. The graphics are great, the gameplay is fun, and the controls are superb. The feeling of adrenaline you get when you are getting overrun by  zombies and your magazine runs dry is just phemomenal.
Its a great game Allot of fun to play! but it has a short Singel player .

This has all the flair of a major development studio, but the execution of a 15-year old. The aiming and locomotion are just frustrating. The sight picture doesn't accurately represent where the round will go. The laser is the only way to guarantee target placement. Reloading is nice, but I found the story lacking. Yet another game that "forces" you to go into a dark place so they can slack on content and feed off "fear" (I can't even say that with a straight face). Poorly executed. Multiplayer is strange and frustrating at times. Definitely not recommended. If you want a good shooter game, Robo Recall is the best out there.

The game has serious problems with  positioning correctly. This is totall random. One day it will work fine, the next day it will move my ammo belt up to my neck. 

There also does not appear to be an option to have multiple campaigns running at the same time. 

I would really like my money back for this one. Though it is fun when it actually works the bugs make it unplayable. I do not accept paying this kind of money for a software that is clearly in beta state.

review_title: Don't Forget to Bring a Towel.
one_reviews_text: Seriously.  It's more tiring than you'd expect, and so fun.  My only complaint is that there is very little indication of what you should do next.  This is not an RPG, and I'm not OK walking around aimlessly for 15 minutes looking for the next puzzle piece.
There is a lot of small things that could and should be improved.

It is hyped a little too much in my humble opinion. I expected a really polished, finished title. It has good ingame vr support, but nevertheless feels like another Unity beta zombie game for me. Playing it with a friend who has a Vive is possible but required me to put the Rift on and off a dozen of times. Activate Portforwarding, sending friend the IP. Ingame the voicechat was broken. Friend did the calibration at the beginning wrong, so we restarted the whole game. Ingame there are random objects flying around attached to the other character. German voiceover destroyes the atmosphere quite often. The dark mine level was no fun at all. It's just complete black without flashlight. Your friend has no orientation if she does not look at the small light cone coming from the flashlight. Technically I think this is just Unity standard absence of light, which I have only seen in cheap alpha-stage games until now.

The Shooting feels good and to blow a zombie's head off is satisfying. The rest is crap, graphics so-so and a pretty non-existent story. There is pretty much no interaction and the puzzles are basically finding something to use in another place. The only reason this game has gotten any attention is because when you are new to vr most stuff is cool, this apply to most of what's out there at the moment. I don't think these games are worth more than 10-20 bucks. I seriously wonder how many of these reviews are fake...

If you've ever wondered what it would be like to be trapped in a zombie apocalypse this is your chance. The graphics are beautiful, the physics are decent, and the controls are well thought out. If you've ever fired a pistol in real life you can play this game.
This is the best VR game.

review_title: one of  the better games so far
one_reviews_text: as far as vr games go, this might be in the top ten right now . probably the best zombie game . but then, there aren't that many good  games out yet .

The ammo belt that is being moved up to you're neck is an easy problem, ya'know there IS a calibration part of the game, when you do it, it shows how tall you are and where it should put the ammo belt, honestly, i LOVE this game, but there is some problems with the walking mode and stuff, but i dont care what people think, giving this 5 stars

Arizona Sunshine was the first VR game I purchased, outside of the free games given with touch.  There are some bugs, especially when it comes to playing Multiplayer.  (You can play with Vive players, just be prepared to jump through some hoops.)  That aside though, shooting feels good, and cracking a zombie with a headshot is pretty awesome.  Story mode isn't as long as you'd hope, and the horde mode is a fun diversion as well that will add a few extra hours.  Thats about all you'll get, but what is here is a pretty good time.

Shooting at zombies is great, weapons are cool, decors are nice (not amazing but nice), but it gets away with sooooo many things because it's VR and somehow things that would be not tolerated in a classical PC game (even Indie) are OK on this platform.
- Scaling !! Cars are biggers than tanks. Objects are all over the place in terms of dimension (bottles etc..)
- Throwing Grenades: I can not for the life of me properly throw a grenade. I mean come on, how hard should it be to throw further than one foot away
- Interacting with objects: you can pretty much pick up anything and then.... do nothing with it. Food an drinks ? well you can only eat burgers, forget about drinking cans. 
- Melee fight: About interacting: You have hammers, axes, giant (see scaling ) pans, all sort of things that scream "smash me in that zombie's face", except that everything that is not a bullet with just go right through them. 
It doesn't have to be robo recall level of collision detection, but please, at least something !
- Polish or lack thereof. Interiors of cars are 1990's level of details. Stray out of where you should you end up staring out the world's sky box
-Zombie movement: there's something off about the zombie movement when they're close to you. I don't know if its bad depth management or jerky movement patterns, but I find it hard to shoot them point blank.  Feels like I have my gun right on their face and somehow it misses.
- Menus: this is common to other VR games. Yes having the menu part of the VR world's experience is fun, the first two minutes, then I don't want to have to fiddle with objects for 5 minutes everytime I want to change a setting or load a game.
This is not a bad game, and all the good points raised in other reviews are valid but I wish that expectations were a bit higher and devs encouraged to go the extra mile to deliver a finished product.
Gameplay is the definition of annoying, better off playing robo recall, at least the guns there shoot straight.
need to play multiplayer... add me plz :/

Very bad traslation, just play in english, and if you don't understand everything don't worry, it's only a zombie game.
worth the cash .story mode short,,,,beat in 2 days
I loved this game a lot...but the only problem is the multiplayer matchmaking...i cant join any online game...its always searching, its not fair!!!!u should fix this...
its like robocall but not nearly as good and more expensive
...but the aim is off which is kind of annoying. I find I'm wasting ammo just to find the sweet spot.

After playing Robo Recall (which I thoroughly enjoyed!) I wanted something with a little more ‘story’ to it and Arizona Sunshine fit the bill perfectly. Some genuinely terrifying stand offs and gun fire that feels really well done. Some great mechanics too (picking up ammo and pocketing in chest and opening draws / car doors, to name a few) that really add to the emersion. I’ve not finished it yet, but I’m really enjoying the story and the somewhat light-hearted script makes it stand out from ‘just another horror game’. My ONLY issue and reason for 4 stars instead of 5, is that of all the games I’ve played, this is the only one I have tracking issues with. Not all the time, but every now and then the screen will lag or hands will jump around, even when in perfect view of the sensors (I’m using 16GB Ram, i7 & GTX 970). The game has been more than engaging enough for me to see past this however and I’m really hoping there’ll be some DLC at a later date for more replayability. Overall, a fantastic game and VR experience. You won’t be disappointed!

I was super excited playing until about an hour in when I made it to the office in the shack. For some reason the play area has an x all over the floor inside and it is unplayable in there now. Sure I can go back outside and shoot zombies, but exploration inside the office shack doesn't work well and i cannot explore the file cabinets. I read that others have had the same problems with tracking. I hope there is an update to this title soon as other games I have don't give me this much grief when playing. Too bad, really cool game so far..

I have been looking at this one for a while, browsing through the positive and negative reviews, but for someone that has a busy life and just wants to enjoy some crazy zombie shooting and isn't a counterstrike expert sniper, this game is a BLAST !

The campaign mode has just enough to get you going, but enough to let you figure out what you can and cannot do.  The movement is great with the warping, however, it does take a while to get the hang of positioning yourself to open boxes and doors and sometimes you can get a dim screen when you warp into something to deeply and have to try and get out again.

The WAVES you experience throughout the game, had my heart pounding, and when eaten alive... wanting to go back and try it again.  (*Sign of a well balanced game imo).

One critisizm I have is the lack of saves.  I was playing it myself and lost my progress on the first night because oif not shutting the game down properly.  The second night I tried Multiplayer, and seemingly, because of that, all my progress was lost AGAIN ! meh !  The game is that new to me I dont care, but I would like to see Multiple save slots or at least profiles in the game.

In short, great graphics, smooth gamplay (Playing on Alienware Laptop with 1080 Graphics Amplifier) scary sound and accurate shooting IMO.  When they get close you will crap your pants and start scrambling.
Oh and the narrative on the campaign was enough to make me smile and laugh all the way through.  Suppose the game merits Kudos or Critisizm based on what you call a Zombie shooter.  But with Robo Recall being the only other VR contender I feel that this game if polished further could be as good.

Great Game...  worth the VR experience !

Annoyed it went on sale on Friday 13th when I payed full price Thursday 12th :-(  Oh well !

4 stars until they add decent save slots, otherwise GET THE GAME !

I like this game but it lacks a certain polish. The graphics are a bit basic as are the levels. Teleporting is a little clunky (I prefer the way Robo Recall implements this) and you can get in a muddle not to mention not being able to jump over things (it would seem). Weapon mechanics can seem a little clunky too. However it's okay and will keep me entertained for some time.

Not played all the way through yet (about 2-3 hours so far), but what I've seen up to now is very enjoyable. I especially like the mining levels where you have to use a torch - quite scary! Playing on normal is actually quite challenging. Yes, there are issues with the iron sights as they do seem a little off, but you get used to it after a while. Some respawn bugs where you are spawned with no ammo - only happened once or twice though. Picked it up on Friday 13th sale, so seems a bargain to me! i5 4690K / 16GB / 1080FTW2 - everything cranked to max - Plays great!

It is good for singleplayer but when I was playing with a friend there were 'connection issues' multiple time while he tried to join my session. This became very frustrating. Also the zombies in multiplayer lag quite a bit and can be quite hard to shoot(particularly the running ones). 

Overall, Its a pretty good game but a lot of work is needed for the multiplayer and maybe some more content.

review_title: Good game but only single player
one_reviews_text: Can't anyone on multiplayer mode. lol empty as hell

As some have stated, the iron sights are off a bit which at times proves to be a little frustrating. People are saying that the story line is great, but there quite literally isn't a story line. It's a L4D type game where the end goal is to escape. The zombies glitch out occassionally. Firstly, they have a stumble animation and when they are in that animation their model lags. To illustrate if you ever played L4D with a low interp and played on Valve's crap servers then the common would lag... it's like that. Secondly, on a few occassions I've had zombies go through walls even on obstacles that are a part of the objective where you have to blow up a wall. The audio in the game is decent, not impressive by any means but not bad. What is bad however is the positional audio. Often you would hear zombies behind you even though they are in front of you. Additionally, the environment doesn't impact sound at all. For instance, in the mines you could hear zombies and have it sound as if they are stuck IN THE WALL. There were a few times where I'd reach a dead end and still hear zombies... makes no sense at all. In terms of immersion breaking, especially in the early stages of the game, zombies would spawn out of these little holes and sometimes spawn in your line of sight. The game obviously has a ton of flaws but I'd say a 3 star rating is quite reasonable. Despite the flaws it is a really fun game and I don't regret buying it. I wish the single player was longer though (it's really short). That being said, if you're not dieing to play this because of the post-apocolyptic setting then maybe wait until it's on sale to purchase it.
shooting zombies in the head...nuff said

I love the pace so far.  Great story line, and outstanding gun play.  It took a second for me to get accustomed to the reload functions, but once I did it turned into a symphony of zombie death.  When I got a good hold of the teleporting, I could manage to move through and clear buildings of the undead in a proper military fashion, and precision worked until the horde descendes, lol.  However, when I had my brother over and gave him a test drive on this game, one thing became clear.  He is red green color blind, and so am I, but to a far lesser extent.  He had trouble seeing the very usefull red dot.  At close range he could see it, but the same shots I was making, he had trouble with because the iron sights don't sync well with the red dot.  I tested this myself in the game.  My prior military backround tells my iron sight aimed shot should of landed a perfect headshot, and when I lined up the red dot and peeped down the irons the sights didn't match.  The solution is either produce better iron sight aim with the dot, or randomely place different colored dot sights through out the game to give different color options.  Would have helped my brother a ton.  All that aside, an outstanding game!
Most entertaining shooter in VR so far.

review_title: One of the TOP 10 GAMES in the Store
one_reviews_text: Fun game! Decent length single player campaign - considering its VR.  Co-Op is a blast. If you have a high end gaming machine, turn up the Supersampling and graphics settings and this game looks great.
This was a great game!  I highly recommend it if you enjoy Zombie shooters.  The gameplay was polished and the story was great.  I hope the creators make a sequel.

Found the game to be very slow, crap mechanics and the teleporter is not very good at all, seem more like a bata than a finishd game.. I hand to turn it off after 10 to 15 minutes.. robo recal is a million times better than this dont wast your money, refund
Game is good, but I have too much bugs : micro freezes, positioning problems, bug as you die and restart from last waypoint.

Using an i7 7700K it was amazing to see all the ingame physics - from dismembering zombies to seeing mosquitoes. This may indeed be the most demanding Rift game. Normally I can use 2.0 supersampling, but in this game I needed to use 1.5 x supersampling, but I could max out every other setting and keep perfect 90+ fps.

review_title: Great Shooting, Short, Some Tech Issues
one_reviews_text:
I'm sure this is in keeping with current VR game design, but the campaign is far too short.  However, there is an arcade-like Horde Mode, where you can test your skill against as many waves as you can handle.  This is fun, but I always find campaigns to be more worth it.  The Horde mode gets repetitive after a time, especially if your trackers decide they're just going to jitter.  The best part of the game, though, are the shooting mechanics.  I shoot in real life, and marksmanship fundamentals play a major role in how accurate you are.  Extremely well done.  Finding a SIG P250C in game was cool.  It's front sight post was a bit thin, though.  I carry the P320C daily, as a point of reference.  Speaking of the weapon models, apart from the 250 and the Beretta 92FS, the other pistols and shotguns seemed improperly scaled.  The two Glocks and the 1911 are too thin, and the shotguns seem small compared to the real life guns they imitate.  The subguns seemed fine, but I haven't held any subgun, so I wouldn't know for sure.  

On the VR sickness front, I was totally fine with locomotion.  Not a single instance of nausea, but I don't get VR sick.  Your mileage may vary.

On the technical side, performance seemed to dip when zombies would enter a stumble animation state, and the trailer park level had incessantly flickering shadows after collecting all the items needed.

TL; DR, Arizona Sunshine is great fun to play, with some of the best shooting mechanics in any VR game I've tried to date.  It does have some minor technical issues, but they don't wear on you.  Extremely well done, and worth the price.

review_title: Great game but needs a ton of memory
one_reviews_text: The game itself is great, immersive and a lot of fun. What's not fun though is the crashes, usually when loading the next area. It doesn't seem very well optimized memory wise since it uses 8GiB of RAM + 8GiB of VRAM with "very high" textures (which are not very high quality at all, merely acceptable). Also, it takes a very long time (almost two minutes) to load, and seems frozen while loading. And sometimes it really is frozen and after a few minutes you remove your headset and see a crash report on the PC screen... Not fun! I solved most of the crashes on my high end PC (GTX 1070 with 8GiB of VRAM) by going back to the "high" textures setting (which results in blurry unreadable text). Once it runs though it runs well (no lag except when a ton of zombies are present). Also, the optional free locomotion is sickening at first, but you get used to it after a while, then it becomes much easier to move around than teleporting while trying to physically stay in front of the Rift's sensors. The story is pretty much inexistent, but the voice acting is good and gives the game an additional dimension. The campaign is quite short for the price (about 3 to 5 hours for $40), but it offers some replay value with the horde mode where you kill as many waves of zombies as you can.

review_title: Pretty good, but def not great
one_reviews_text: After seeing so many great reviews of Arizona Sunshine, I couldn't wait to play. Now that I have, I have to say that, while I enjoyed it compared to a lot of other VR "games" out there, I wasn't as impressed as I expected I'd be. First of all, the graphics are okay... but, even turned up all the way, kind of meh. Robo Recall blows it out of the water, for sure. Secondly, I experience a LOT of judder in this game, even after turning the graphics down a couple of notches. I don't have that problem with any other game, VR or not. In fact, I bought a beast of a computer and have been able to crank every game up to Ultra with no problem whatsoever. Only Arizona Sunshine struggles. Thirdly, the design feels a little unfinished. There's no melee, and there are useful-looking objects sprinkled throughout that you can pick up but which don't do anything. For instance, there are medpacks everywhere that you can grab, but they don't do anything. Just props. You only get health from burger patties. There are water bottles that appear full but do nothing. Backpacks, canned food, etc. Look useful, but all just decorative. As a dev at major studios since 1995, I can say it feels like they intended to have more pickups but then either ran out of time or balanced gameplay down to only a couple of pickups w/o removing the universally recognized "useful" objects (why have an obvious army "medkit" that's grabbale but useless?). Beyond that, the game is repetitive. Move from A to B, picking off stragglers. Fight a big horde at the checkpoint. Rinse and repeat. Searching cars is cool, though the only thing to find is ammo. Also, the aiming feels wonky. Overall, it feels like *most* of a game... but is not quite there. I hope they keep developing it, but because it's not marked "early access," I assume this is it. Still, it's fun and a step forward for VR games. That being said, you get a much better experience with Robo Recall and that's free!

There are 3 must buy games with touch controls right now and this is one of them!  The other two being Super Hot and Call of the Starseed.  I really enjoyed Starseed, but its very short, Arizona Sunshine on the other hand is the first VR game with touch controls I've played that feels like an actual, full-on game experience.  The control scheme is fantastic.  You can hold a gun in each hand, with an additional gun holstered on your right and left hip.  By looking down you can see how much ammo you have of each gun, and you'll see your grenades hanging on the right of your chest.  Once you start to get the hang of things the more intense fire fights will have you quick swapping your left gun for the one on your left hip while you fire with your right hand gun, grab a grenade, toss it, reload, destroy zombies.  After playing starseed I did wish I had a backpack so I could throw excess ammo and food into it, but it turns out that there's enough food and ammo located near spots where big fights happen that you'll be fine.  If story is what is most important to you, play Call of the Starseed, a short but pleasant story.  This games story amounts to your character talking to himself throughout the game.  As a fan of apocalyptic Walking Dead type fiction I enjoyed being a loner who talks to himself and is most likely a little batty.  The gameplay is where this game shines.  Once I found a revolver that looked like rick grimes' gun I never put it down.  You'll pick up some other fun weapons as well, I won't spoil that.  Nothing super crazy but after finding multiple pistols it truly feels empowering to find some weapons more powerful than pistols... I still stuck with my Rick Grime's Revolver for the most part.  The game looks beautiful.  I typically can't handle horror games, and I liked that this one isn't about horror and scare tactics. I love this game and highly recommend it!  Cheers!!

You did it, you added the full locomotion! Whether you guys had planned the implementation from the start or did it because many of us were requesting it, THANK YOU.
5 STARS!!!

Aim is right on now (you can test this by using the laser sight on easy) and I was even able to shoot zombies off cliffs way above me.   I would put this in the top few with SuperHot and I Expect You to Die.  I only experienced one bug (I could not get into the mines after killing all the zombies, I think a zombie was stuck behind an object on a cliff), but replayed that part and it worked.  Not a single issue since.  The mines are very scary and the environment is spooky too.  I definitely panicked a few times to the point I dropped my guns and flashlight.  

Not sure why others are having issues, but I'm using Windows 10, i7 3930K OCd to 4.2Ghz and a GTX 1070.   I ensure no other programs are running in the background (that includes setting your anti-virus not to do idle auto-scans which crushes your CPU during games).  Using 3 sensors and tracks perfectly.  Again, I did experience issues with the Steam version when it was first released, but the Oculus version seems to work very well now.  I play short chunks of time, checkpoints allow for that and game length seems reasonable.  Compared to other VR releases, this is a great game.

Hope this helps someone!

UPDATE 15th Dec 
Have now played the game a substantial amount, and not only am I glad I bought it, I strongly recommend everybody do. It's one of the few full length singleplayer experiences in VR right now.  

It's an intense experience. One minute you are a sharpshooting badass, calmly headshotting slow zombies one at a time as they advance towards you. Next minute you are a shrieking child, blindly hip-firing entire magazines of ammo into a clump of fast zombies that are charging at you, wishing you hadn't used your last grenade.

The shooting is juuuust difficult enough to feel rewarding when you are headshotting the aforementioned slow zombies. But also juuuust easy enough that when you turn around and get surprised by that pack of fast zombies, you can still come out of it alive without burning through all your ammo.

review_title: Triple A in VR, But Not Perfect
one_reviews_text:
This is the first game where I felt like I was playing a non-experimental VR title. This comes with a interesting narrative, plenty character and quality visuals. --- The game has a real aim mechanic that requires you to actually line up the shot, and pick off the zombies one by one (preferably via headshot.) Getting the shot just right is incredibly satisfying. Scavaging I found to be quite rewarding and fun as well, opening doors and trunks of cars made me feel like a Walking Dead character.

 --- However, it also comes with the lineararity and diluted mechanic quality of said triple A titles; Teleporting around proves to be an even bigger hassle than the potential simulator sickness of locomotion, especially in tense situations when your teleport beam is obstructed by invisible and obscure bounding boxes, leading to your death more often than not. Giving the option for artificial locomotion is a MUST for games like these, as the teleporting system actively prevents me from enjoying the game a lot of the time. I also end up accidentally hitting the analog stick and turning ninty degrees when I two hand handguns for much needed aiming assistance during waves (the option to turn this off would be amazing for this reason.) One other big gripe I have is that there seems to be no way, to my knowledge, to pause the game without exiting, which is a pain if you need to briefly exit VR and haven't hit a checkpoint yet.

 --- All in all, I'm really enjoying the game. But the control scheme shoots itself in the foot for the sake of comfort. If we were allowed to turn these comfort features off for something that is more responsive, it would significantly improve the game.
